title: If a book is published and then the publisher dissolves, and the author dies, who owns the rights? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer, as always, is “it depends.” Let’s trace things… The volume was first written, creating a copyright in that work. Depending on the circumstances under which it was written the copyright might be with the author at this point, or with the entity for which the work was done (often the publisher in the case of a “work for hire”). If the author controlled the copyright then for publication to happen, some rights would have to be assigned to the publisher. In the case of books it’s common for authors to sell some portion of the rights; e.g. “first North American print publication” rights can be sold separately from “first worldwide digital publication” rights. Rights sold under contract can be for terms, can have renewal options, and so on. If the entity that controlled the rights (say, the publisher) goes out of business, those rights are part of the assets of the company. At dissolution, a company’s assets are usually assigned to pay off creditors and so on. It’s possible these rights were assigned in that way to some other entity. It’s also possible that the contract had reversion clauses in it. Often these clauses stipulate that if a work goes out of print rights revert back to the author, or in the case of dissolution of the owning entity rights might also revert. It’s all based on contract language none of us know. In many cases, contracts aren’t drawn properly to handle all these circumstances and a work becomes an “orphan” - that is, something for which copyright exists but the owner of that copyright either no longer exists or cannot be found. Unfortunately, although there has been some legal progress in the treatment of orphan works, there’s still no good universally established framework for handling them.
